awd_titl_txt: The Role of High Impact Practices for STEM Persistence and Career Success
awd_abstract_narration:
Kenyon College will award scholarships to low income, academically talented students, supporting them with high-impact practices (HIPs) to increase their persistence and graduation. Scholars will be engaged over four years, exposing them to HIPs early in their undergraduate careers, since the majority of students nationwide who leave STEM fields do so during their first two years. Activities begin with a summer learning community, and continue with structured and unstructured service learning projects, faculty-student mentoring, and internships and research opportunities.

Four annual cohorts of 12 low-income, high-achieving students with interests across the STEM disciplines will receive scholarships.  The project will test and evaluate the impact of STEM-focused HIPs beneficial to first-year students, aiming to increase persistence of these STEM students, especially those from groups with traditionally lower STEM degree completion rates.  The research component of the project will also identify HIPs most likely to result in students pursuing STEM careers.  An external expert will provide formative and summative evaluation of program impact, as well as future sustainability.  Kenyon will contribute findings of best practices to the field, and will make special effort to share research emerging from its testing of HIPs and other programs in the liberal arts, for which there is little STEM-specific data.

por.por_cntn:
We sought to increase STEM persistence, graduation, and career success by providing scholarships and by exposing STEM Scholars to high-impact practices (HIPs) early in their undergraduate careers, when students are most at risk of leaving STEM fields. We particularly sought to improve outcomes for students from groups with traditionally lower STEM degree completion rates. Annual cohorts of 12-15 academically talented, financially needy students received scholarships and engaged in HIPs, beginning with a summer learning community, and continuing with structured and unstructured service learning projects, faculty-student mentoring, and a career development workshop. Scholars also had opportunities for mentored research, STEM internships, professional meeting attendance, peer tutoring through our Math and Science Skills Center and Writing Center, and engagement in STEM affinity groups and clubs. 


The overall retention rate of STEM Scholars was above 92%, slightly higher than at Kenyon overall (90%). The graduation rate in our first three cohorts was 95%, higher than the 86% four-year graduation rate for Kenyon students overall, and markedly higher than for Pell recipients (82%), or students who identify as Black or African American (78%), Hispanic or Latino (79%), or Asian (83%), categories which are over-represented in the STEM Scholars cohorts. Moreover, 92% of STEM Scholars who remained at Kenyon completed a STEM major, better than the approximately 67% national rate for students who start college with an interest in STEM. Not only did most STEM Scholars complete STEM majors, but they also moved into positions of leadership as teaching assistants, peer tutors and mentors, and leaders of student groups. In addition, many earned awards including collegiate and departmental honors, election to honor societies, and nationally competitive fellowships and scholarships.

Based on the success of the program and its relation to the mission of the College, the STEM Scholars program has been sustained beyond the grant funding period, including both scholarship funding and HIP-based programming. Collaborations with STEM faculty and relevant campus offices, including Admissions, Academic Advising, the Career Development Office, and Student Affairs, have been maintained and expanded. Our program was assessed through evaluation of specific activities and through surveys and focus groups conducted by external evaluators on an annual basis, and results were disseminated at several conferences.

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2023
Modified by: Karen A Hicks
